text: Plural ignorance or pluralistic ignorance is a term which gives a name to a situation where a majority of group members privately reject a norm, but at the same time, they assume incorrectly that most others accept it.Daniel Katz and Floyd H. Allport. (1931). Students' Attitudes: A Report of the Syracuse University Reaction Study, pp. 152-153. The term describes a context in which "no one believes, but everyone thinks that everyone believes."Centola, Damon, Robb Willer, and Michael Macy. 2005. "The Emperor’s Dilemma: A Computational Model of Self-Enforcing Norms," American Journal of Sociology, Vol. 110, No 4 (January 2005), pp. 1009–1040; retrieved 2013-3-1. A context of plural ignorance can be caused by the structure of the underlying social network.Kitts, James A. "Egocentric Bias or Information Management? Selective Disclosure and the Social Roots of Norm Misperception," Social Psychology Quarterly, Vol. 66, No. 3 (September 2003), pp. 222-237; retrieved 2013-3-1. A situation of plural ignorance develops when each individual decision-maker in a group of decision-makers does not have the necessary information to solve a problem.Henricks, Vincent F. and Pelle G. Hansen. (2011). Oplysningens blinde vinkler (Enlightenment blind spots), p. 17. ==History== The term pluralistic ignorance was coined by Daniel Katz and Floyd H. Allport in 1931. Plural ignorance may partially explain why people are more likely to intervene in an emergency situation when alone than when other persons are present.Baumeister, Roy F. and Brad J. Bushman. (2010). Social Psychology and Human Nature, p. 280. If people monitor the reactions of others in such a situation, they may conclude from the inaction of others that other people think that it is not necessary to act. ==Related pages== * The Emperor's New Clothes * False consensus * Intensity of preference ==References== Category:Psychology
title: Plural ignorance
